Few studies have qualitatively examined the experiences of patients and healthcare personnel following a nurse-led health literacy intervention to prevent readmission. Methods This exploratory qualitative process evaluation was conducted within a randomized controlled trial aimed at understanding the perspectives of both patients and professionals following the implementation of a health literacy intervention. The intervention includes home visits conducted by nurses trained in COPD, employing motivational interviewing techniques and supporting the development of individualised treatment plans post-hospital discharge. Eight semi-structured interviews with patients, one focus group, and one individual interview with healthcare providers ( n Results Two main themes arose among patients: “Building health literacy through personalized nursing support” and “From knowledge to action: Strengthening health literacy through motivational support” – and two among healthcare professionals; “Health professionals’ experience of developing health literacy competency” and “Perceived shifts in understanding, roles, and relationships through health literacy awareness”. Conclusion The nurse-led health literacy intervention was perceived as valuable by both patients and healthcare professionals. Patients described how home-based support from competent nurses may have contributed to a better understanding of post-discharge care and fostered a sense of preparedness. Professionals reported gaining insights into patient needs, which they felt enabled more tailored communication and care planning. While the findings are based on a small qualitative sample, they suggest that such interventions may support the transition from hospital to home. Furthermore, new collaborative relationships, various health personnel competencies and communication systems across different health care services were established. Inspired by the Ophelia process, the study comprises three phases. In phase one, we identified health literacy needs through focus groups and a health literacy survey [ 10 11 9 9 9 16 17 Aim The present paper focuses on the process evaluation of the intervention by exploring the experiences of patients participating in the intervention group and the healthcare personnel who performed the intervention. Results from the other phases have been published separately [ 9 11 18 Methods The Consolidated Criteria for Reporting Qualitative Research (COREQ) checklist was used during the development and reporting of the study [ 19 Design This study has an explorative, descriptive, qualitative design. It was nested within the RCT study and conducted before the trial's results regarding the effectiveness of the COPD-HL intervention were known [ 18 Rationale for the multi-perspective approach We included both patient and healthcare professional perspectives based on the understanding that health literacy interventions function within complex health systems shaped by patient-provider interactions. Research shows their effectiveness depends on patient engagement and providers’ ability to adapt communication [ 20 Personal characteristics of the research team Two female researchers (AKW & MHL) conducted individual interviews with the patients with COPD and one of the study nurses (AKW). MHL led a focus group with other healthcare professionals (HCP), supported by a research assistant for note-taking and observation. At the time of the study, MHL was an associate professor at a Norwegian nursing college (master's studies) and a senior researcher at the University of Oslo. AKW is a professor at the University of Oslo and a senior researcher at Oslo University Hospital. CRB serves as the head researcher and principal investigator of the RCT study, and is a senior researcher at the recruiting hospital, and an associate professor at the University of Oslo. Relationship with participants The interviewers had no prior acquaintance with the patients. Some HCP had casual familiarity with the interviewers, while others did not. Participants were informed that the interviewers' involvement was due to their research expertise and not direct implementation of the project. Neither interviewer had prior experience in COPD care, reducing any assumptions about participant responses. Study setting and recruitment Participants with COPD were recruited by a study nurse after the intervention, interviewed six months later, and before the final one-year follow-up (with no intervention during this period). Purposeful sampling aimed to gather diverse post-intervention experiences. The inclusion criteria for the intervention included a COPD diagnosis, age over 18, and admission for COPD on the medical unit. Exclusion criteria comprised documented cognitive impairment and cancer treatment. Interviews with all healthcare professionals took place after data collection concluded at the one-year follow-up in December 2020, which was delayed due to the COVID-19 epidemic. Health literacy informed intervention The health literacy intervention was a collaboration between a medium-sized hospital in Oslo, Norway, and four municipal health departments: Grünerløkka, Gamle Oslo, St.Hanshaugen and Sagene. It entailed eight weeks of home follow-up post-hospitalisation by nurses trained in COPD care and motivational interviewing (MI). These nurses also worked in the hospital ward where patients were admitted. Additionally, patients received four months of telephone support and could contact the nurses during the day if needed (see Fig. 1 9 Fig. 1 Content of the health literacy intervention in people with COPD Data collection Patients who had taken part in the health literacy intervention (FGD number: 2017/1281), were approached by a study nurse during post-intervention data collection. Only participants in the intervention group were interviewed to address the article’s objective. Three of the approached patients declined to be interviewed due to COPD-related fatigue. The RCT study is registered on ClinicalTrials.gov, 7/7–2017 (ID: NCT03216603 An interview guide with open-ended and follow-up questions regarding various aspects of study participation was employed (see Supplementary files 1& 2). The guide was not pilot-tested, but participants were encouraged to freely share their experiences, and probing questions, like ‘What do you mean by that?’ ‘Could you tell me more?’ was used for clarification. Interviews conducted either in the patient's home or the hospital, ranged from 20 to 90 min. No one else participated in the individual interviews except for the interviewer and the patient. The focus group and healthcare professional interviews lasted approximately 90 min and were conducted in the hospital`s administration building. One researcher served as the moderator, while another acted as the secretary in the focus group. All interviews were conducted in Norwegian and were audio recorded and transcribed verbatim. They were not returned for comments or corrections. Data analysis Reflexive thematic analysis guided by Braun and Clarke’s six phases (i.e. familiarising oneself with the data, generating initial codes, searching for themes, reviewing the themes, defining and naming the themes and report production) [ 21 1 22 23 Table 1 Details of the analysis steps Steps to reflexive thematic analysis Details of analysis Step 1: Familiarising oneself with the data CRB, MHL and AKW read all the transcripts to gain a general impression of the data from both the patient and health care personnel interviews Step 2: Generating initial codes The same three authors read and coded the eight individual patient interviews independently and then met and coded together using Nvivo software to draft the first codebook. Hence, the transcripts were examined on a line-by-line basis with codes assigned to segments of the data and an initial coding frame developed The patient interviews were coded first to let the patients` voices guide the analysis. Then, the same three authors independently coded the transcriptions from the focus group interview with health care personnel and one individual interview with one of the nurses using the codebook from the patient interviews and, through discussion, agreed on additional new codes to assure the relevance of the codebook. Some codes were only relevant for the patients and some for the HCPs. This process was flexible; the texts were often double- and triple-coded; and the codes had to be re-evaluated and adjusted. The text was sorted into 47 codes from patients and HCPs Step 3: Searching for themes Codes were gradually expanded into broader categories through comparison across transcripts, and higher-level recurring themes were developed. All data relevant to each potential theme were gathered. Every theme with connected data extractions was read and coded to identify the core elements of the theme and check whether the themes were logical and meaningful Step 4: Reviewing themes The themes were checked to determine whether they worked on the coded extracts (level 1) and the entire data set (level 2). A visual mind map was created during one of the later workshops to create a general idea about the themes and subthemes to avoid missing the overall picture and determine what was relevant to the research question related to experiences participating in the intervention. Subthemes were identified; certain data extracts were moved to a different theme, and specific themes were split, whereas others were renamed and merged All the transcriptions were then re-read to check the validity of the themes. No further adjustments were needed Step 5: Defining and naming themes A short text capturing the core story of each theme relevant to answering the research question was formed. Illustrative quotes were identified Step 6: Producing the report This step involved relating to the analysis of the research question and literature and reporting the analysis. Vivid, compelling extract examples were selected Rigour and reflexivity Lincoln and Guba [ 24 25 26 25 19 Findings Participants characteristics The average age of the patients who participated in the interviews was 69, with a range of 58–86 years. The median time since diagnosis of COPD was 15 years, with a range of 0–29 years. There were four men and two women, approximately 50% lived alone, and 25% had more than four years of higher education. Of the healthcare professionals who followed up with the patients, five were nurses, and one was a pulmonary physician. All were females, and their ages ranged from 27 to 40 years. Building health literacy through personalised nursing support In this first theme, the three subthemes reflect different aspects of the patient`s experience of receiving home follow-up and the interactions with the visiting nurse; 1) Learning to navigate COPD knowledge within life's complexities 2) Competence and trust go hand in hand and 3) From confusion to confidence: participants'experiences of personalized health education. All interviewed patients expressed overall positive experiences with nurses'home visits, citing newfound COPD knowledge, practical adjustments, and technical equipment provided by the nurses. Several patients expressed a desire for continued follow-up with hospital-based nurses. In ‘ Learning to navigate COPD knowledge within life's complexities 3 3 In the second subtheme, ‘ Competence and trust go hand in hand 3 3 In the third subtheme, ‘ From confusion to confidence: participants'experiences of personalized health education 3 Theme 2: From knowledge to action: strengthening health literacy through motivational support This second main theme consists of two sub themes; 1) Motivation for positive lifestyle change and 2) The importance of a treatment plan. In this theme, the patients talked about the consequences of the COPD intervention on their lifestyle- and treatment choices. The motivational interviewing techniques and the nurses` empathy were assessed as positive, and many of the patients experienced the treatment plan as an important measure to gain more control of their COPD symptoms. In the first subtheme describing motivation for positive lifestyle change 4 Another patient, who had recently quit smoking after 45 years, described the importance of project nurses providing positive reinforcement for his efforts. The informant reported finding motivation in colleagues'positive comments about improved physical endurance at work and described experiencing reduced breathing problems and less mucus. However, the most significant motivation was not wanting to deceive the project nurse, who regularly inquired about the progress as a non-smoker. Patients believed that early medication use, guided by the plan, could, in some situations prevent hospitalization (Table 4 Perspectives of healthcare professionals The second part of the themes is based on the interviews with the nurses and the doctor who had participated in the intervention. These interviews led to two main themes 1) Health professionals` experience of developing health literacy competency, 2) Descriptions of new understandings, roles, and relationships through health literacy knowledge. Theme 3: Health professionals’ experience of developing health literacy competency This theme includes three subthemes: (1) The need to acquire new knowledge and competence, (2) communicating differently with MI, and (3) the treatment plan as a tailored compass for action. The nurses discussed how meeting patients in their homes made them rethink the challenges faced by individuals living with COPD. They emphasised the importance and challenges of learning and applying motivational interviewing techniques and developing new skills such as writing treatment plans and gaining more knowledge on COPD-related topics like nutrition, smoking cessation, and pulmonary function tests. They described noting changes in their communication styles after the intervention, with a heightened awareness of the patients'home environments (Table 6 6 Discussion and conclusion Discussion This study aimed to qualitatively evaluate a health literacy intervention by exploring the experiences of both patients and healthcare personnel in the intervention group. Process evaluation that focuses on more than efficacy and effectiveness is recommended by the framework for the development and evaluation of complex interventions (i.e. the Medical Research Council’s framework for developing and evaluating complex interventions [ 16 Most participants described positive views of the intervention, and both patients and healthcare workers reported enhanced COPD knowledge. COPD self-management is complex, requiring collaboration between patients and professionals to define their roles. The emotional and clinical burden reported by patients with COPD is consistent with existing literature [ 27 28 29 30 31 However, participants described how focusing on health literacy with MI techniques and nonjudgmental communication by nurses motivated them to seek knowledge and adopt positive health behaviors, similar to other COPD studies [ 32 33 12 34 35 36 37 Our study found that patients receiving the health literacy intervention highly valued practical solutions to their issues. They especially reported appreciating nurses consulting the hospital's lung specialist to facilitate prescription arrangements, avoiding the need for a GP visit. Similar results are evident in another COPD study [ 38 39 40 41 42 Strengths and limitations of the study Strengths include the fact that the researchers who conducted patient interviews had no prior knowledge of the participants, or the healthcare professionals involved in the study, reducing potential bias. However, there may be some recall bias among the nurses due to the long-time interval between project completion and the interviews. All healthcare provider participants were female, which may limit the transferability of findings to healthcare settings with more gender-diverse teams. Male healthcare providers may possess different communication styles, perspectives, or approaches to health literacy interventions that could influence patient experiences and outcomes. Furthermore, the gender dynamics between our all-female provider sample and both male and female patients may have created specific interaction patterns that affect the generalisability of results to varying provider-patient gender combinations. The interviewed participants may not fully represent the diversity of individuals with severe COPD. Only one participant was from an ethnic minority background, despite the RCT cohort encompassing a broad demographic, social, and clinical spectrum. Additionally, the study primarily featured one doctor, and other healthcare professionals, such as physiotherapists, nutritionists, or those from community healthcare services who consulted the nurses, were not interviewed. Furthermore, while the inclusion of both patient and healthcare professional perspectives enriched the study by offering a more holistic view of the intervention’s impact, we acknowledge that the analysis maintained separate thematic structures for each group. This approach preserved the integrity of their distinct experiences but limited opportunities for a more integrated synthesis. A more in-depth comparative analysis, exploring convergences, divergences, and complementary insights between patients and providers, could have further strengthened the findings and offered more nuanced implications for practice and implementation. Member checking was not conducted to verify the accuracy of transcripts and interpretations with participants, which represents a missed opportunity to enhance the credibility and trustworthiness of our findings through participant validation. The sample size—eight patient interviews and six healthcare professional interviews—was small, but deemed sufficient based on the concept of information power [ 43 Mixing interviews and focus groups might limit the depth of discussion on certain topics, as these methods offer different possibilities for exploration. Another limitation is the inclusion of only intervention arm participants, without control arm participants for comparison. This means we cannot compare participants ‘ experiences with those who did not receive the intervention, limiting our understanding of what aspects of the experience were specifically related to the intervention components. Another key limitation of this study is the absence of clinical data regarding participants’ COPD severity (e.g., GOLD stage or spirometry results). This restricted our ability to explore how disease stage may have influenced patients’ experiences and needs within the health literacy intervention. While the intervention was designed to be individualised and responsive to each patient’s functional status and expressed concerns, we acknowledge that patients at different stages of COPD may require different types and intensities of support. Overall, while the study provides valuable insights into participants’ experiences, the findings should be viewed as exploratory and hypothesis-generating. Future studies with larger, more diverse samples could explore the transferability to other contexts and populations. Future research should also incorporate clinical indicators to enable a more nuanced understanding of how disease progression shapes HL needs and outcomes. Relevance to clinical practice The study highlights the importance of understanding and respecting patients with COPD`s perspectives and knowledge for effective treatment. The collaborative negotiation of patient-professional relationships is key to health literacy and self-management in COPD follow-up. Whether from hospitals or municipalities, patients and healthcare professionals must collaborate to define their roles and responsibilities in addressing health literacy, self-management, and timely treatment of exacerbations. Conclusion The nurse-led health literacy intervention was perceived as valuable by both patients and healthcare professionals. Participants described how home-based support contributed to a better understanding of post-discharge care and fostered a kind of preparedness. Healthcare professionals reported gaining greater awareness of patient needs for involvement, which they felt enabled more tailored and empathetic support. However, COPD self-management remains complex and requires ongoing collaboration between patients, professionals, and health care services. While these findings are based on a small qualitative sample, they suggest that such interventions may support patient-centered COPD care transitions when healthcare professionals possess appropriate health literacy competencies. We confirm all patient/personal identifiers have been removed or disguised so the patient/person(s) described are not identifiable and cannot be identified through the details of the story. Authors’ contributions CRB, AKW, and MHL were responsible for the study's literature search, conception, and design. CRB recruited participants for the interviews. AKW and ML were responsible for data collection. CRB, AKW and MHL analysed and interpreted the data. MHL wrote the first draft of the manuscript. All authors wrote substantial parts and critically revised the manuscript. All authors, CRB, AKW, and MHL, were responsible for writing and revising the manuscript and have approved the final article. Data are available from PI Christine R Borge, mail: c.r.borge@medisin.uio.no for researchers who meet the criteria for access to confidential data. Declarations Ethics approval and consent to participate The study is in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and the Health Research Act. It was approved by the ethical committee of South East, Oslo, Norway (2016/12981/REK sør-øst), and research data protection officers at Lovisenberg Diaconal Hospital, and the RCT, on which this study is based, is registered in the clinical trials database. All participants received information about the purpose of the study, voluntary participation, the option to withdraw at any time, and confidentiality for all data. Participants signed written informed consent before participating in the interviews. The written interviews and audio recordings were stored in the research database of the main research hospital. Consent for publication Not applicable.
